title: 114_s1550
content:
The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" establishes governmentwide standards for program and project management. The Deputy Director for Management is responsible for overseeing the implementation of these standards and policies. The "Program Management Improvement Accountability Act" sets standards for program and project management across agencies. It includes engaging with the private sector for best practices, conducting portfolio reviews, and establishing a 5-year strategic plan. The Department of Defense is exempt if similar provisions are already in place. The Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget must issue standards, policies, and guidelines within 1 year. Regulations must be issued within 90 days after the standards are released to implement the requirements of the Program Management Improvement Accountability Act. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act requires agencies to designate Program Management Improvement Officers to implement program management policies and enhance the role of program managers through training and educational opportunities. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act mandates training for program and project managers in the private sector, focusing on relevant competencies and cost containment for large projects and programs. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act includes mentoring, improved career paths, recruitment plans, best practices dissemination, and data analysis tools for program managers. The Act does not apply to the Department of Defense if similar provisions are already in place. The Program Management Improvement Accountability Act establishes the Program Management Policy Council to improve agency practices related to program and project management. The Council advises the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, reviews high-risk programs, and discusses workforce development needs. The Program Management Policy Council advises on workforce development needs, policy for program management improvement, and challenges in program management across agencies. It also reviews governmentwide standards for program management transparency and information published on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Program Management Policy Council advises on workforce development needs, policy for program management improvement, and challenges in program management across agencies. It also reviews governmentwide standards for program management transparency and information published on the Office of Management and Budget's website. The Deputy Director for Management, Administrator of the Office of Electronic Government, Administrator of Federal Procurement Policy, Controller of the Office of Federal Financial Management, and Director of the Office of Performance and Personnel Management are key positions within this council. The Program Management Policy Council, chaired by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, includes agency representatives and other designated federal employees. The Council meets at least twice per fiscal year and supports workforce development and program management improvement. The Program Management Policy Council, chaired by the Deputy Director for Management of the Office of Management and Budget, meets regularly and receives administrative support from agency heads. A report on the strategy developed under this Act must be submitted to Congress within a year. Regulations for program and project management personnel standards must be issued within 180 days. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management, in consultation with the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, will issue regulations within 180 days to identify key skills and competencies, establish new job series, and create a career path for program and project managers in agencies. The Government Accountability Office will report on the effectiveness of policies on program and project management within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The Government Accountability Office will assess the effectiveness of standards, policies, guidelines, strategic plans, Program Management Improvement Officers, and the Program Management Policy Council on improving Federal program and project management.
